clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Medical Cannabis and Prescription Opioid Taper Support for Reduction of Pain and Opioid Dose in Patients With Chronic Non-Cancer Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Medical Cannabis and Prescription Opioid Taper Support for Reduction of Pain and Opioid Dose in Patients With Chronic Non-Cancer Pain

brief_summary.textblock: This study will use a randomized controlled design to test whether medical marijuana use by adults on high-dose chronic opioid therapy (COT) for chronic non-cancer pain (CNCP) is associated with reduced opioid dose and improved pain severity when added to a 24-week behavioral intervention (POTS).

detailed_description.textblock:
This trial is a randomized, six-month study of medical marijuana (MM) on opioid use that will: (1) evaluate whether adults with CNCP on COT assigned to MM+POTS, compared with those assigned to WL+POTS, have greater reduction in opioid dose and/or pain severity, (2) assess whether participants assigned to MM+POTS, compared with those assigned to WL+POTS, have improved quality of life, improved pain interference, depression, and anxiety; and improvement in cognitive functioning, (3) evaluate whether those assigned to MM+POTS develop symptoms of CUD over the 24-week intervention, as well as at the 12-month time point.
Participants will be randomly assigned to either an active MM arm (n = 125), or to a waitlist control arm (WLC) (n = 125). Participants will be assessed at baseline, every 4 weeks for 6 months, and at a 12-month follow-up for opioid use, development of CUD, development or resolution of OUD, and neurocognitive performance. Urine collected at each visit will be assessed with quantitative assays.

primary_outcome.description: The opioid dose (MME/day) will measure any change in use.
The pain severity sub-scale of the Brief Pain Inventory - Short Form will assess pain severity symptoms. The scale ranges from 0 - 40, with a higher score indicating greater pain severity.

secondary_outcome.description: Quality of Life Enjoyment and Satisfaction Questionnaire - Short Form will assess changes in quality of life measures. The scale ranges from 14 - 70, with a lower score indicating greater dissatisfaction with life.

The pain interference sub-scale of the Brief Pain Inventory - Short Form will assess pain interference symptoms. The scale ranges from 0 - 70, with a higher score indicating greater pain interference.
The depression sub-scale of the PROMIS-29 will be used to assess depression symptoms. The scale ranges from 0 - 21, with a higher score indicating greater depression.
The anxiety sub-scale of the PROMIS-29 will be used to assess anxiety symptoms. The scale ranges from 0 - 21, with a higher score indicating greater anxiety.

The DSM-5 Opioid Use Disorder Checklist will evaluate symptoms of Opioid Use Disorder (number of symptoms). The scale ranges from 0 - 11, with a higher score indicating more severe Opioid Use Disorder.

The DSM-5 Cannabis Use Disorder Checklist will evaluate symptoms of Cannabis Use Disorder (number of symptoms). The scale ranges from 0 - 11, with a higher score indicating more severe Cannabis Use Disorder.

other_outcome.measure: Changes in Cognitive Functioning: verbal memory
other_outcome.description: Verbal learning will be assessed through the CVLT-III
Attention will be assessed using the Connors CPT

other_outcome.measure: Changes in Cognitive Functioning: working memory
other_outcome.description: Working memory will be assessed using the WAIS

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Men and women aged 18-75, inclusive.
2. Endorsing > 6 months of CNCP.
3. On stable prescription opioid doses of at least 25 MME for >90 days.
4. Either no prior use or current light cannabis use (weekly or less in the past 12 months).
5. Desire to use medical cannabis for pain to control pain and/or reduce opioid dose.
6. Competent and willing to provide written informed consent in English.
7. Potential participants of childbearing potential must have a negative urine pregnancy test at enrollment and agree to use effective contraception: abstinence; hormonal contraception; intra-uterine device, sterilization; or double barrier contraception, during the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Current cannabis use of greater than weekly on average in the past 12 months, assessed via self-report.
2. Current major medical illness, such as cancer, symptomatic hypothyroidism/hyperthyroidism or severe respiratory compromise.
3. Use of non-prescribed opioids, by self-report or urine toxicology screen.
4. Actively suicidal and/or suicide attempt or psychiatric hospitalization in past year, or current suicidal ideation with specific plan or intent.
5. History of intellectual disability (e.g., Down's syndrome) or other severe developmental disorder or IQ < 70.
6. Current diagnosis of delirium, dementia, amnestic, or other cognitive disorder; lifetime schizophrenia or other psychotic disorder; bipolar I disorder; clinically significant diagnosis of borderline, antisocial, paranoid, schizoid, schizotypal or histrionic personality disorder.
7. Surgery within the past month or planned during the next 6 months.
8. Pregnant or trying to get pregnant or breastfeeding.
9. In the opinion of the investigator or study physicians, not able to safely participate in this study.
